leanChapterLines.displayTitle: Chapter 3 Provisions for All Compliance Methods
Chapter 18 Minimum Requirements for the Mandatory Milestone Inspections
Appendix A Guidelines for the Seismic Retrofit of Existing Buildings
Appendix C Refer to NFPA 914 Code for Fire Protection of Historic Structures 2001 Edition
Resource A Guidelines on Fire Rating of Archaic Materials and Assemblies

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall apply where a change of occupancy occurs, as defined in Section 202.

A change of occupancy or a change of occupancy within a space where there is a different fire protection system threshold requirement in Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building shall not be made to any structure without the approval of the code official. A certificate of occupancy shall be issued where it has been determined that the requirements for the change of occupancy have been met.

Any work undertaken in connection with a change in use that does not involve a change of occupancy classification or a change to another group within an occupancy classification shall conform to the applicable requirements for the work as classified in Chapter 6 and to the requirements of Sections 1002 through 1011.
Exception: As modified in Section 1205 for historic buildings.

Where the occupancy classification of a building changes, the provisions of Sections 1002 through 1012 shall apply. This includes a change of occupancy classification and a change to another group within an occupancy classification.
Exception: A single-family or two-family dwelling that is converted into a certified recovery residence, as defined in s. 397.311, Florida Statutes or a recovery residence, as defined in s. 397.311, Florida Statutes that has a charter from an entity recognized or sanctioned by Congress does not have a change of occupancy as defined in this Code solely due to such conversion.

diagrams.title: Occupancy Groups of the Building Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Occupancy groups are classifications designated to buildings or structures based on their primary use or purpose. This classification accounts for the similar hazards and risks to building occupants that arise from the intended function of the building. These designations help in defining safety and building requirements specific to each group.

children.displayTitle: 1001.2.2 Change of Occupancy Classification or Group
children.titleText: Change of Occupancy Classification or Group

children.body: Where the occupancy classification or group of a portion of an existing building is changed, Section 1012 shall apply.
A certificate of occupancy shall be issued where a change of occupancy occurs that results in a different occupancy classification as determined by the Florida Building Code, Building.

Where an existing building or part of an existing building undergoes a change of occupancy to one of the special use or occupancy categories as described in Chapter 4 in the Florida Building Code, Building, the building shall comply with all of the applicable requirements of Chapter 4 of the Florida Building Code, Building applicable to the special use or occupancy.

Where a portion of a building undergoes a change of occupancy to one of the incidental uses listed in Table 509.1 of the Florida Building Code, Building the incidental use shall comply with Section 509 of the Florida Building Code, Building applicable to the incidental use.

Where a change of occupancy occurs to a Group I-2 or I-1 facility, the work area with the change of occupancy shall comply with the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: A change in use or occupancy in the following cases shall not be required to comply with the Florida Building Code, Building:
  1. Group I-2, Condition 2 to Group I-2, Condition 1.
  2. Group I-2 to ambulatory health care.
  3. Group I-2 to Group I-1.
  4. Group I-1, Condition 2 to Group I-1, Condition 1.
children.displayTitle: 1002.3 Change of Occupancy in Health Care
children.titleText: Change of Occupancy in Health Care

children.body: In Group I-2 occupancies, equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 of the Florida Building Code, Building, where a room 250 square feet (23.2 m2) or less undergoes a change in occupancy to a storage room, the room shall be separated from the remainder of the building by construction capable of resisting the passage of smoke in accordance with Section 509.4.2 of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Building elements and materials in portions of buildings undergoing a change of occupancy classification shall comply with Section 1012.

Fire protection requirements of Section 1012 shall apply where a building or portions thereof undergo a change of occupancy classification or where there is a change of occupancy within a space where there is a different fire protection system threshold requirement in Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Means of egress in portions of buildings undergoing a change of occupancy classification shall comply with Section 1012.
Accessibility in portions of buildings undergoing a change of occupancy classification shall comply with the provisions of the Florida Building Code, Accessibility.

Buildings or portions thereof subject to a change of occupancy where such change in the nature of occupancy results in higher uniform or concentrated loads based on the Florida Building Code, Building, Table 1607.1 shall comply with the gravity load provisions of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: Structural elements whose stress is not increased by more than 5 percent.

Buildings and structures subject to a change of occupancy where such change in the nature of occupancy results in a higher wind risk category based on the Florida Building Code, Building Table 1604.5, (High-Velocity Hurricane Zones shall comply with Section 1620) shall be analyzed and shall comply with the applicable wind load provisions of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: Where the new occupancy with a higher risk category is less than or equal to 10 percent of the total building floor area. The cumulative effect of the area of occupancy changes shall be considered for the purposes of this exception.

Where the occupancy of an existing building or part of an existing building is changed to one of the following special occupancies as described in NFPA 70, the electrical wiring and equipment of the building or portion thereof that contains the proposed occupancy shall comply with the applicable requirements of NFPA 70 whether or not a change of occupancy group is involved:
  1. Hazardous locations.
  2. Commercial garages, repair, and storage.
  3. Aircraft hangars.
  4. Gasoline dispensing and service stations.
  5. Bulk storage plants.
  6. Spray application, dipping, and coating processes.
  7. Health care facilities.
  8. Places of assembly.
  9. Theaters, audience areas of motion picture and television studios, and similar locations.
  10. Motion picture and television studios and similar locations.
  11. Motion picture projectors.
  12. Agricultural buildings.

Where the occupancy of an existing building or part of an existing building is changed, all unsafe conditions shall be corrected without requiring that all parts of the electrical system comply with NFPA 70.
Where the occupancy of an existing building or part of an existing building is changed, electrical service shall be upgraded to meet the requirements of NFPA 70 for the new occupancy.

diagrams.title: GFCI locations - Other than Dwellings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A GFCI outlet, or Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter outlet, is a type of electrical outlet designed to protect people from electric shock. This is achieved by comparing the incoming and outgoing currents. If there is an imbalance, the GFCI outlet quickly interrupts the power to prevent injury.

children.body: Where the occupancy of an existing building or part of an existing building is changed, the number of electrical outlets shall comply with NFPA 70 for the new occupancy.

Where the occupancy of an existing building or part of an existing building is changed such that the new occupancy is subject to different kitchen exhaust requirements or to increased mechanical ventilation requirements in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Mechanical, the new occupancy shall comply with the respective Florida Building Code, Mechanical provisions.

Where the occupancy of an existing building or part of an existing building is changed such that the new occupancy is subject to increased or different plumbing fixture requirements or to increased water supply requirements in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Plumbing, the new occupancy shall comply with the intent of the respective Florida Building Code, Plumbing provisions.
Exception: Only where the occupant load of the story is increased by more than 20 percent, plumbing fixtures for the story shall be provided in quantities specified in the Florida Building Code, Plumbing based on the increased occupant load.

If the new occupancy is a food-handling establishment, all existing sanitary waste lines above the food or drink preparation or storage areas shall be panned or otherwise protected to prevent leaking pipes or condensation on pipes from contaminating food or drink. New drainage lines shall not be installed above such areas and shall be protected in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Plumbing.
If the new occupancy will produce grease or oil-laden wastes, interceptors shall be provided as required in the Florida Building Code, Plumbing.

If the new occupancy will produce chemical wastes, the following shall apply:
  1. If the existing piping is not compatible with the chemical waste, the waste shall be neutralized prior to entering the drainage system, or the piping shall be changed to a compatible material.
  2. No chemical waste shall discharge to a public sewer system without the approval of the sewage authority.
If the occupancy group is changed to Group I-2, the plumbing system and medical gas system shall comply with the applicable requirements of the Florida Building Code, Plumbing.
Where the occupancy or group of an existing building or part of an existing building is changed, single-user facilities that are or will be provided shall be permitted to comply with Section 810.1.
Light and ventilation shall comply with the requirements of the Florida Building Code, Building for the new occupancy.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

children.body: The provisions of this section shall apply to buildings or portions thereof undergoing a change of occupancy classification. This includes a change of occupancy classification within a group as well as a change of occupancy classification from one group to a different group or where there is a change of occupancy within a space where there is a different fire protection system threshold requirement in Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building. Such buildings shall also comply with Sections 1002 through 1011. The application of requirements for the change of occupancy shall be as set forth in Sections 1012.1.1 through 1012.1.4. A change of occupancy, as defined in Section 202, without a corresponding change of occupancy classification shall comply with Section 1001.2.

diagrams.title: Change of Occupancy / Change of Use: Definition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the Existing Building Code, a Change of Use is defined as a change in the use of a building or a portion of a building, within the same group classification, for which there is a change in application of the code requirements.

diagrams.title: Change of Occupancy Group
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where a building or portion thereof undergoes a change in occupancy the building or portion thereof needs to be re-evaluated for compliance with the following:
  • Sprinkler system per Chapter 9
  • Special use / occupancy requirements per 1002
  • Building Elements and Materials per 1011
  • Fire Sprinkler per 1011.2.1
  • Fire Alarm per 10011.2.2
  • Means of Egress per 1011.5
  • Structural per 1006
  • Electrical per 1007
  • Mechanical per 1008
  • Plumbing per 1009
  • Light and ventilation per 1010

diagrams.title: Change of Occupancy Classification
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where a building or portion thereof undergoes a change in occupancy the building or portion thereof needs to be re-evaluated for compliance with the following:
  • Sprinkler system per Chapter 9
  • Special use / occupancy requirements per 1002
  • Building Elements and Materials per 1011
  • Fire Sprinkler per 1011.2.1
  • Fire Alarm per 10011.2.2
  • Means of Egress per 1011.5
  • Structural per 1006
  • Electrical per 1007
  • Mechanical per 1008
  • Plumbing per 1009
  • Light and ventilation per 1010

children.body: The requirements of Chapter 9 shall be applicable throughout the building for the new occupancy classification based on the separation conditions set forth in Sections 1012.1.1.1 and 1012.1.1.2.

Where a portion of an existing building is changed to a new occupancy classification or where there is a change of occupancy within a space where there is a different fire protection system threshold requirement in Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building, and that portion is not separated from the remainder of the building with fire barriers having a fire-resistance rating as required in the Florida Building Code, Building for the separate occupancy, the entire building shall comply with all of the requirements of Chapter 9 applied throughout the building for the most restrictive occupancy classification in the building and with the requirements of this chapter.
children.displayTitle: 1012.1.1.1 Change of Occupancy Classification Without Separation
children.titleText: Change of Occupancy Classification Without Separation

children.body: Where a portion of an existing building is changed to a new occupancy classification or where there is a change of occupancy within a space where there is a different fire protection system threshold requirement in Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building, and that portion is separated from the remainder of the building with fire barriers having a fire-resistance rating as required in the Florida Building Code, Building for the separate occupancy, that portion shall comply with all of the requirements of Chapter 9 for the new occupancy classification and with the requirements of this chapter.
children.displayTitle: 1012.1.1.2 Change of Occupancy Classification With Separation
children.titleText: Change of Occupancy Classification With Separation

children.body: The provisions of Sections 1012.2 and 1012.3 for fire protection and interior finish, respectively, shall apply to all buildings undergoing a change of occupancy classification.

The relative degree of hazard between different occupancy classifications shall be determined in accordance with the categories specified in Tables 1012.5, 1012.6 and 1012.7. Such a determination shall be the basis for the application of Sections 1012.5 through 1012.8.
children.displayTitle: 1012.1.3 Change of Occupancy Classification Based on Hazard Category
children.titleText: Change of Occupancy Classification Based on Hazard Category

children.body: All buildings undergoing a change of occupancy classification shall comply with Section 1012.9.

Where a change of occupancy occurs to a Group I-2 or I-1 facility, the work area with the change of occupancy shall comply with the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: A change in use or occupancy in the following cases shall not be required to meet the Florida Building Code, Building:
  1. Group I-2, Condition 2 to Group I-2, Condition 1.
  2. Group I-2 to ambulatory healthcare.
  3. Group I-2 to Group I-1.
  4. Group I-1, Condition 2 to Group I-1, Condition 1.
Fire protection systems shall be provided in accordance with Sections 1012.2.1 and 1012.2.2.

Where a change in occupancy classification occurs or where there is a change of occupancy within a space where there is a different fire protection system threshold requirement in Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building that requires an automatic fire sprinkler system to be provided based on the new occupancy in accordance with Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building, such system shall be provided throughout the area where the change of occupancy occurs.

Where a change in occupancy classification occurs or where there is a change of occupancy within a space where there is a different fire protection system threshold requirement in Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building that requires a fire alarm and detection system to be provided based on the new occupancy in accordance with Chapter 9 of the Florida Building Code, Building, such system shall be provided throughout the area where the change of occupancy occurs. Existing alarm notification appliances shall be automatically activated throughout the building. Where the building is not equipped with a fire alarm system, alarm notification appliances shall be provided throughout the area where the change of occupancy occurs in accordance with Section 907 of the Florida Building Code, Building as required for new construction.

In areas of the building undergoing the change of occupancy classification, the interior finish of walls and ceilings shall comply with the requirements of the Florida Building Code, Building for the new occupancy classification.

In Group E occupancies, where the work area is a Level 3 alteration, enhanced classroom acoustics shall be provided in all classrooms with a volume of 20,000 cubic feet (565 m3) or less. Enhanced classroom acoustics shall comply with the reverberation time in Section 808 of ICC A117.1.
Hazard categories in regard to life safety and means of egress shall be in accordance with Table 1012.5.

When a change of occupancy classification is made to a higher hazard category (lower number) as shown in Table 1012.5, the means of egress shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 10 of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exceptions:
  1. Stairways shall be enclosed in compliance with the applicable provisions of Section 903.1.
  2. Existing stairways including handrails and guards complying with the requirements of Chapter 9 shall be permitted for continued use subject to approval of the code official.
  3. Any stairway replacing an existing stairway within a space where the pitch or slope cannot be reduced because of existing construction shall not be required to comply with the maximum riser height and minimum tread depth requirements.
  4. Existing corridor walls constructed on both sides of wood lath and plaster in good condition or 1/2-inch-thick (12.7 mm) gypsum wallboard shall be permitted. Such walls shall either terminate at the underside of a ceiling of equivalent construction or extend to the underside of the floor or roof next above.
  5. Existing corridor doorways, transoms and other corridor openings shall comply with the requirements in Sections 805.5.1, 805.5.2 and 805.5.3.
  6. Existing dead-end corridors shall comply with the requirements in Section 805.6.
  7. An operable window complying with Section 1012.5.6 shall be accepted as an emergency escape and rescue opening.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

children.displayTitle: 1012.5.1 Means of Egress for Change to Higher Hazard Category
children.titleText: Means of Egress for Change to Higher Hazard Category

children.body:
When a change of occupancy classification is made to an equal or lesser hazard category (higher number) as shown in Table 1012.5, existing elements of the means of egress shall comply with the requirements of Section 905 for the new occupancy classification. Newly constructed or configured means of egress shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 10 of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: Any stairway replacing an existing stairway within a space where the pitch or slope cannot be reduced because of existing construction shall not be required to comply with the maximum riser height and minimum tread depth requirements.
children.displayTitle: 1012.5.2 Means of Egress for Change of Use to Equal or Lower Hazard Category
children.titleText: Means of Egress for Change of Use to Equal or Lower Hazard Category

children.body: Egress capacity shall meet or exceed the occupant load as specified in the Florida Building Code, Building for the new occupancy.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Gallery
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When designing a building with floors that contain rooms or areas dedicated to different functions, it's essential to calculate the design occupant load for each area independently, as specified in section 1004.3. The occupant load factor (OLF) for each specific function is determined by Table 1004.5. Architects and engineers must differentiate between net and gross floor areas in their calculations. Net floor area excludes unoccupied accessory spaces such as corridors, stairs, ramps, restrooms, and closets, while gross floor area encompasses these accessory spaces.

The design process involves categorizing various areas according to their function within the building. To calculate the occupant load, divide the area (whether net or gross) of each function by its corresponding OLF from Table 1004.5, then sum the occupant loads for all functions. Designers may encounter scenarios where a space's function doesn't directly match any listed in the table. In such cases, it's necessary to choose the function that most closely aligns with the intended use of the space. For instance, an art gallery with common workshop areas for activities like framing paintings, or more production-like activities like welding and other fabrication processes could classify these workshops under an industrial area, as it most closely resembles the activities' nature, according to Table 1004.5.

diagrams.title: Occupant Load Calc: Small Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Single-Occupancy Category B, Restaurant, Non-Sprinklered

UpCodes Note: Restroom/Corridor is not normally occupied area, and major use is assembly (seating), based on "net area". Restroom/Corridor area is excluded from occupant load calculation.

The determination of occupant loads and occupancy groups are independent. Even though the occupancy group for a small assembly area may be a Group B occupancy group, the occupant load factor for "Assembly: Without Tables and Chairs" would be used if the space functions in that way. The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the space level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

When adding additional occupant loads, be sure and verify with other code requirements, such as accessibility, exit discharge and also separate bathroom requirements, are not violated. In this instance, increasing the occupant load to larger than what is allowed for a single user restroom could require an additional restroom be added, making the proposed addition problematic. In cases such as this, close working with the Building Official and consideration of the Existing Building code requirements should be considered to determine if an additional bathroom should be added.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Retail
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Even though the restroom and corridor is not normally occupied area, the major use is Mercantile. Based on the definition of "gross area", the restroom and corridor area is included in occupant load calculation. The diagram shown is based on the 2018 codes which allows an Occupant Load Factor of 150 instead of 100 for business areas.

The building code does not specifically address whether to round occupant loads up at the room level, or the overall space. Rounding at the room level is shown here. Check with your local jurisdiction for local policies on rounding.

diagrams.title: Concentrated Business Use (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Occupant loads are determined by dividing the square footage of a space by the occupant load factor, for the use of the space, as shown in this table. This example shows a business occupancy. To account for the total occupant load each space must be calculated on its intended use. In the example the business occupancy is further separated into concentrated business use, assembly spaces, and collaboration spaces. The occupant load factor, per Table 101:7.3.1.2, allows 150 sq.ft/person for general business use. If it is a concentrated business use, then the allowance is reduced to 50 sq.ft./person. The annex information for this section from NFPA describes concentrated business use as, "The value for concentrated business use is intended to address business use spaces with a higher density of occupants than would normally be expected in a general business occupancy. Where furnishings and floor layouts are arranged to maximize the number of occupants in the space, the value for concentrated business use should be applied. Examples of concentrated business use areas are call centers, trading floors, and data processing centers."

Additionally, our example shows several collaboration spaces. Collaboration spaces less than 450 sq.ft. are factored at 30 sq.ft/person, greater than 450 sq.ft. at 15 sq.ft./person. These are defined by NFPA as, "Collaboration rooms/spaces are common to office buildings. Their principal function is to permit collaboration among occupants in the privacy of a small room/space. These rooms/spaces are primarily used by occupants of the business occupancy to transition temporarily from their regular workstation area in order to obtain privacy and to avoid disturbing other employees located in the open office environment. Collaboration rooms/spaces have been commonly referred to as quiet rooms, focus rooms, huddle rooms, and team rooms." Some confusion may be had as to whether a space is considered a conference room or a collaboration space. For the most part, and AHJ, will refer to whatever the space is named on the drawing and apply that occupant load factor. However, if a collaboration space is greater than 450 sq.ft. the occupant load factor is reduced to 15 sq.ft./person. As the primary function of a conference room, as opposed to a collaboration space, is for the purpose of assembly, those spaces larger than 450 sq.ft can be considered a "less concentrated use" assembly space. The occupant load factor still remains at 15 sq.ft./person.

diagrams.title: Occ. Loads: Business and Concentrated Business Use
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If more workstations are present than the value of OLF=50 would allow, the Building Official may approve a higher occupant load. If not approved, the maximum number of occupants would be based on an OLF = 50. The Code states Where approved by the building official, the occupant load for concentrated business use areas shall be the actual occupant load but not less than one occupant per 50 square feet.

diagrams.title: Min. Stairway Widths - Exceptions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: There are three conditions in which the occupant egress capacity factor changes when determining minimum stairway egress width. In a building that is fully sprinklered and equipped with and emergency voice/alarm communication system (EVACS), the occupant egress capacity factor can be increased to 0.2" per person. This does not apply to Group H or I-2 occupancy classifications. In a facility having smoke-protected assembly seating the occupant egress capacity factor for stepped aisles shown in Table 1029.6.2 can be used. The smoke control system must comply with Section 909. In a facility having open-air assembly seating the occupant egress capacity factor for stepped aisles shown in Section 1029.6.3 can be used.

children.body: Existing stairways shall comply with the handrail requirements of Section 805.9 in the area of the change of occupancy classification.
Existing guards shall comply with the requirements in Section 805.11 in the area of the change of occupancy classification.

diagrams.title: Guards:  Connection Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
ASCE 7 requires the 200 pound load to be placed in any direction at any point on the handrail or top rail to produce a maximum load effect. This would mean a load pulling on the rail inward would create a maximum tension on the bottom bolt, but a 200 pound force outward (typically associated with "falling" outward) would put the maximum tension on the top bolt.

However, the Residential Code, in Table R301.5, footnote d, states: "A single concentrated load applied in any direction at any point along the top. For a guard not required to serve as a handrail, the load need not be applied to the top element of the guard in a direction parallel to such element." This language does not seem to appear in ASCE 7 at this time.

Therefore, the designer should consider providing tension resisting hardware on both bolts, or consider an alternate design. Simply relying on the rim board would put the member into cross-grain bending, which has considerably lower strength than the beam itself.

diagrams.title: Guards: Stairs (Non-Res)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guardrails at stairs for that are not within a multifamily dwelling unit or for an R-3 residential occupancy have more robust requirements than is required for those that are residential in nature. Verify with the Existing Building Code what requirements must be met when removing / replacing a guardrail, as more current requirements can be more restrictive than when the railing was installed.

diagrams.title: Guards At Stairs (Res)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guardrails at stairs for that are not within a multifamily dwelling unit or for an R-3 residential occupancy have more robust requirements than is required for those that are residential in nature. Verify with the Existing Building Code what requirements must be met when removing / replacing a guardrail, as more current requirements can be more restrictive than when the railing was installed.

children.body:
Where a change of occupancy would require emergency escape and rescue opening in accordance with Section 1030.1 of the Florida Building Code, Building operable windows serving as the emergency escape and rescue opening shall comply with the following:
  1. An existing operable window shall provide a minimum net clear opening of 4 square feet (0.38 m2) with a minimum net clear opening height of 22 inches (559 mm) and a minimum net clear opening width of 20 inches (508 mm).
  2. A replacement window where such window complies with both of the following:
    1. The replacement window meets the size requirements in Item 1.
    2. The replacement window is the manufacturer's largest standard size window that will fit within the existing frame or existing rough opening. The replacement window shall be permitted to be of the same operating style as the existing window or a style that provides for an equal or greater window opening area than the existing window.
children.displayTitle: 1012.5.6 Existing Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings
children.titleText: Existing Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings

children.body: Hazard categories in regard to height and area shall be in accordance with Table 1012.6.

When a change of occupancy classification is made to a higher hazard category as shown in Table 1012.6, heights and areas of buildings and structures shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 5 of the Florida Building Code, Building for the new occupancy classification.
Exception: For high-rise buildings constructed in compliance with a previously issued permit, the type of construction reduction specified in Section 403.2.1 of the Florida Building Code, Building is permitted. This shall include the reduction for columns. The high-rise building is required to be equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 of the Florida Building Code, Building.
children.displayTitle: 1012.6.1 Height and Area for Change to Higher Hazard Category
children.titleText: Height and Area for Change to Higher Hazard Category

children.body:
In other than Groups H, F-1 and S-1, fire barriers and horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Sections 707 and 711, respectively, of the Florida Building Code, Building shall be permitted to be used in lieu of fire walls to subdivide the building into separate buildings for the purpose of complying with the area limitations required for the new occupancy where all of the following conditions are met:
  1. The buildings are protected throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with the Florida Fire Prevention Code.
  2. The maximum allowable area between fire barriers, horizontal assemblies, or any combination thereof shall not exceed the maximum allowable area determined in accordance with Chapter 5 of the Florida Building Code, Building without an increase allowed for an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 506 of the Florida Building Code, Building.
  3. The fire-resistance rating of the fire barriers and horizontal assemblies shall be not less than that specified for fire walls in Table 706.4 of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: Where horizontal assemblies are used to limit the maximum allowable area, the required fire-resistance rating of the horizontal assemblies shall be permitted to be reduced by 1 hour provided the height and number of stories increases allowed for an automatic sprinkler system by Section 504 of the Florida Building Code, Building are not used for the buildings.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions

children.body: When a change of occupancy classification is made to an equal or lesser hazard category as shown in Table 1012.6, the height and area of the existing building shall be deemed acceptable.
children.displayTitle: 1012.6.2 Height and Area for Change to Equal or Lesser Hazard Category
children.titleText: Height and Area for Change to Equal or Lesser Hazard Category

children.body:
When a change of occupancy classification is made to a higher hazard category as shown in Table 1012.6, fire barriers in separated mixed use buildings shall comply with the fire-resistance requirements of the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: Where the fire barriers are required to have a 1-hour fire-resistance rating, existing wood lath and plaster in good condition or existing 1/2-inch-thick (12.7 mm) gypsum wallboard shall be permitted.
Hazard categories in regard to fire-resistance ratings of exterior walls shall be in accordance with Table 1012.7.

When a change of occupancy classification is made to a higher hazard category as shown in Table 1012.7, exterior walls shall have fire resistance and exterior opening protectives as required by the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exception: A 2-hour fire-resistance rating shall be allowed where the building does not exceed three stories in height and is classified as one of the following groups: A-2 and A-3 with an occupant load of less than 300, B, F, M or S.
children.displayTitle: 1012.7.1 Exterior Wall Rating for Change of Occupancy Classification to a Higher Hazard Category
children.titleText: Exterior Wall Rating for Change of Occupancy Classification to a Higher Hazard Category

children.body: When a change of occupancy classification is made to an equal or lesser hazard category as shown in Table 1012.7, existing exterior walls, including openings, shall be accepted.
children.displayTitle: 1012.7.2 Exterior Wall Rating for Change of Occupancy Classification to an Equal or Lesser Hazard Category
children.titleText: Exterior Wall Rating for Change of Occupancy Classification to an Equal or Lesser Hazard Category

children.body:
Openings in exterior walls shall be protected as required by the Florida Building Code, Building. Where openings in the exterior walls are required to be protected because of their distance from the lot line, the sum of the area of such openings shall not exceed 50 percent of the total area of the wall in each story.
Exceptions:
  1. Where the Florida Building Code, Building permits openings in excess of 50 percent.
  2. Protected openings shall not be required in buildings of Group R occupancy that do not exceed three stories in height and that are located not less than 3 feet (914 mm) from the lot line.
  3. Where exterior opening protectives are required, an automatic sprinkler system throughout may be substituted for opening protection.
  4. Exterior opening protectives are not required when the change of occupancy group is to an equal or lower hazard classification in accordance with Table 1012.7.
Enclosure of vertical shafts shall be in accordance with Sections 1012.8.1 through 1012.8.4.
Vertical shafts shall be designed to meet the Florida Building Code, Building requirements for atriums or the requirements of this section.

When a change of occupancy classification is made to a higher hazard category as shown in Table 1012.5, interior stairways shall be enclosed as required by the Florida Building Code, Building.
Exceptions:
  1. In other than Group I occupancies, an enclosure shall not be required for openings serving only one adjacent floor and that are not connected with corridors or stairways serving other floors.
  2. Unenclosed existing stairways need not be enclosed in a continuous vertical shaft if each story is separated from other stories by 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction or approved wired glass set in steel frames and all exit corridors are sprinklered. The openings between the corridor and the occupant space shall have at least one sprinkler head above the openings on the tenant side. The sprinkler system shall be permitted to be supplied from the domestic water-supply systems, provided the system is of adequate pressure, capacity, and sizing for the combined domestic and sprinkler requirements.
  3. Existing penetrations of stairway enclosures shall be accepted if they are protected in accordance with the Florida Building Code, Building.

Interior vertical shafts other than stairways, including but not limited to elevator hoistways and service and utility shafts, shall be enclosed as required by the Florida Building Code, Building when there is a change of use to a higher hazard category as specified in Table 1012.5.
Exceptions:
  1. Existing 1-hour interior shaft enclosures shall be accepted where a higher rating is required.
  2. Vertical openings, other than stairways, in buildings of other than Group I occupancy and connecting less than six stories shall not be required to be enclosed if the entire building is provided with an approved automatic sprinkler system.

All openings into existing vertical shaft enclosures shall be protected by fire assemblies having a fire protection rating of not less than 1 hour and shall be maintained self-closing or shall be automatic-closing by actuation of a smoke detector. All other openings shall be fire protected in an approved manner. Existing fusible link-type automatic door-closing devices shall be permitted in all shafts except stairways if the fusible link rating does not exceed 135°F (57°C).
Existing buildings that undergo a change of group or occupancy classification shall comply with the provisions of the Florida Building Code, Accessibility.
Reserved.
Reserved.
See the Florida Building Code, Energy Conservation.
